Occupant Centric Control (OCC) strategies aims to achieve a more personalized and comfortable indoor environment, translating occupants' comfort requirements into real environmental conditions. This strategy relies on a multilevel non-linear programming optimization procedure to determine optimal thermo-hygrometric setpoints. The objective is to minimize space heating and cooling requirements while addressing multi-domain comfort concerns related to individual thermal sensations and perceived air quality. To facilitate this process, this study adopts a novel Personal Comfort Model (PCM), incorporating physiological factors to predict occupants' thermal sensations and CO2 intakes. The PCM's reliable predictive capabilities are confirmed through validation with real experimental data from a test room at the University of Perugia. For detailed energy analyses, considering occupants' subjective comfort preferences, the PCM is seamlessly integrated into DETECt, an in-house building energy performance simulation tool developed by the University of Naples Federico II, for the design of advanced control algorithms and energy efficiency strategies. To effectively manage the HVAC system, a model predictive control is implemented, using the determined setpoints to ensure mechanical ventilation and maximize cost savings. The proof of concept for the developed methodology involves simulating experimental tests using the thermal model of the human body and the new facility management system, to be simulated and optimized by means of the enhanced building energy performance simulation tool, exploited for the design and operation of more occupant-centric and sustainable buildings. The proposed study demonstrates that through the developed OCC strategy enables a significant reduction in thermal discomfort (40 % and 60 % less than the occupation time for test 1 and test 2, respectively) compared to reference scenarios. Additionally, energy analysis reveals high efficiency, achieving savings of 12.8 % and 7.8 % of electricity consumed for HVAC system operation. Keywords Physiological thermal comfort models Building energy performance simulation tools Human-body thermal sensation Occupant centric control Multi-level nonlinear programming MPC control for HVAC Multi-domain comfort model Perceived indoor air quality Data availability Data will be made available on request. Efforts are being made worldwide to understand the best practices that lead to a more sustainable use of the resources, while maintaining acceptable levels of comfort for occupants. However, the ongoing global population growth, which reached eight billion people in 2022 [2], claims for the development of innovative solutions to improve living conditions without compromising the environment and the ability of future generations to meet their needs. People typically spend about 90 % of their time indoors [3], that have a significant impact on their well-being and quality of life, and on the energy use. This has led to dedicated efforts to improve occupants’ comfort perception, especially considering the narrow relationship between indoor environmental quality (IEQ) and people’s health, well-being, productivity and social interactions [4]. Particularly, building active systems are being more demanded to maintain acceptable levels of satisfaction, which increases buildings’ energy use even with the energy efficiency trends demonstrated in recent reports and standards [5]. Designers, architects, engineers, and construction managers must work together and set shared commitments to create healthier, sustainable and energy efficient indoor spaces by continuously improving the design, operation, and user engagement to achieve a harmonious equilibrium between energy consumption and occupants’ comfort. Classical thermal comfort models were already largely explored in literature, introducing approaches that try to describe occupants’ comfort perception with certain environmental conditions. Fanger introduced in the 60 s a fairly simple approach to predict the Predicted Mean Vote (PMV) and the Percentage of People Dissatisfied (PPD) based on key environmental parameters collected through experimental monitoring, and personal characteristics. As a result, the control and operation of buildings' heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems have been based on constant setpoints, chosen conservatively by designers to accommodate worst-case scenarios; this practice frequently results in over sizing of system components and inefficient energy use. Occupant-centric control strategies approaches can be explored, since static comfort setpoints may not accurately reflect the actual dynamic nature of occupant behaviour and thermal comfort requirements [6,7]. Although the important contribution that classical models had added to the scientific discussion, occupants are still considered as passive to the thermal sensations and their adaptation potential, linked to physiological and cultural aspects, are often neglected [8]. Neglecting the adaptation potential of occupants can result in occupant dissatisfaction and suboptimal building performance, and increased energy costs. To address these issues, building professionals must recognize and consider occupants' adaptive behaviour in the design and operation of buildings. It is crucial to investigate the use of Building Energy Performance Simulations (BEPS), by implementing novel and adaptive comfort models. This will allow for accurately evaluating occupants' dynamic thermal comfort requirements and assessing how buildings perform in terms of energy use, thermal comfort, and other environmental factors [9] Ultimately, adaptive comfort models implemented in building energy performance simulations provide a powerful tool for designing and operating indoor spaces that prioritize occupant well-being while achieving energy efficiency and sustainability goals. 1.1 The role of physiological response for human body comfort Researchers are more recently switching from the general approaches, based on experimental steady-state conditions and general assumptions, to a more personalized perspective. Personal Comfort Models (PCM) are designed to address the individual variation in occupants’ environmental preferences. PCMs moves away from the traditional one-size-fits-all approach and embraces a more personalized and precise methodology, incorporating indicators that provide deeper insights into the subjects’ comfort requirements. These models utilize a range of indicators, such as physiological signals, environmental data, and personal characteristics, to develop data-driven approaches through advanced modelling algorithms [10]. Specifically, physiological data is able to overcome the lack of personal adaptation of models to suit occupants’ particular preferences, as well as capturing thermal comfort under transient scenarios [11]. Therefore, by considering environmental conditions, PCMs ensure that the comfort predictions are tailored to the unique characteristics of each space [12]. Furthermore, PCMs recognize the significance of personal characteristics in determining comfort preferences including factors such as age, gender, clothing, and activity level which influence an individual’s thermal comfort requirements. Specifically referring to the thermal environment, a PCM must consider that the thermal comfort sensation strongly depends on thermoregulatory mechanisms – which in turn activate dynamic responses of physiological parameters [13]. Metabolic rates, for example, can describe the body heat balance mechanism, depending on the human-environment energy exchanged, having thus an important effect on thermal sensation [14]. Indeed, to adopt constant and standardized values of metabolic rates may not represent realistic criteria to model thermal comfort perception and occupants’ needs given the individual variability and the different activity level that people perform during the day. Basically, thermogenesis, i.e., metabolic heat production, is estimated through a basal value plus the additional heat production, derived from thermoregulation, shivering and exercising [15]. Physiological signals are particularly helpful to estimate this additional heat production, considering the thermoregulation processes. Human body targets maintaining physiological homeostasis during everyday activities, result of the interaction with the environment. When in discomfort, the autonomic nervous systems operate more intense activity [16] and the activation of the sympathetic nerve, indicated also by the heart rate variation (HRV), that may describe thermal comfort afterwards [17]. Fiala et al. [15] described human thermoregulation system using a dynamic model of the human body, applying physiological data to equation’s determination. Model validation was carried out with experimental data and comparison with other models, obtaining satisfactory results to prediction of human thermal and regulatory response in different conditions. A more recent version, the Fiala’s UTCI multi-node model, also includes the adaptive clothing model for outdoor climates and ultimate model’s validation [18]. Some authors performed model validation to predict physiological signals in different activity levels [18], clothing combination [19] and demanding environmental conditions [20]. Efforts to reduce the complexity in modelling these phenomena aim to make their implementation in BEPS tools more feasible, while maintaining high levels of accuracy. Looking for facilitate also the data collection process, wearables sensors are suitable options to capture human response to different stimuli of comfort domains reducing subjects’ fatigue, suitable for laboratory tests and real-world experiments, due to precision, commercial availability and non-intrusiveness [21]. Li et al. [22] used wearable devices to monitor skin temperature and heart rate, to later propose optimal temperature settings for reducing energy use and improving comfort, through reinforced learning algorithms. The authors found out that is possible to improve both metrics, in the early stages of HVAC system operation. 1.2 Managing occupant-centric control through physiological information Occupant-centric control (OCC) systems take advantage of monitoring data from occupants, indoor and outdoor environments, and human-building interaction to build operation patterns, such as occupancy schedules, shading configuration, and thermostat settings [23]. Basically, OCC is a process able to incorporate monitored data to a control method managed by algorithms, that seek to ensure occupant comfort and energy efficiency [24]. OCC strategies can deal with the conflicting occupant-systems relationship, considering the energy costs to maintain adequate comfort levels, hardly obtained on traditional manual control strategies [25]. Great energy saving opportunities can be found only by coordinating the HVAC systems accordingly to the occupants’ presence, such as the study carried out by Pang et al. [26] found out by comparing different climate zones, building sizes and standards. O’Neill et al. [27], on the other hand, presented a method that dynamically adjust the minimum air flow rate to guarantee adequate levels of CO2 concentration in each calculated zone thus also introducing the air quality dimension in addition to the thermal one. However, the scientific body of knowledge concerning multi-domain interaction in the indoor environment is still incipient, while the single-domain analysis presents already a considerable number of works [28]. This asymmetry rises probably because the difficulty to measure and analyse multi-domain data, leading to inconclusive or contradictory outcomes [29]. However, in the last years, researchers have been more engaged in explored multi-domain approaches, particularly focusing on two factors thermal conditions and indoor air quality [30]. In addition to these agents, occupants’ behaviour is, in turn, a personal response, varying due to individual preferences and occasional influences. Furthermore, it is crucial to acknowledge that occupants play a significant role in shaping their own behaviour within a given environment. These variations in behaviour can be attributed to a range of factors, such as personal inclinations, cultural backgrounds, external influences, and occasional motivations [31]. It is challenging to fully identify tailored solutions and human-centric variables by means of general models fed by building-related sensors and targeting the average response. Personalised monitoring signals can overcome this challenge, by the proposal of data-driven models to the decision-making of conditioning systems setpoint, ventilation use, lighting adjustments etc. Despite its popularity in the last years among human-centric comfort researchers, OCC operation lacks real application with empirical data, obtained by clear experimental design and models capable of emulate the real human experience [23]. Experiences in test rooms can be a starting point to implement and test OCC techniques, bringing simulation suppositions to the real-world application, when new approaches are investigated [30]. Physiological data from the occupants can also assist in the determination of building operation metrics, minimising the subjective and randomness aspects of human’ control [32]. Li and Chen [33] trained a convolutional neural network (CNN) capable of identify the mean facial skin temperature and relate to thermal sensation votes. From that, a system which controls the HVAC setpoint was proposed, obtaining more than 90 % of acceptability when implemented. Deng and Chen [34] measured skin temperature through wristbands and indoor environmental conditions achieving savings of 90 % for heating and 30 % for cooling systems. However, the adoption of black-box modelling for predicting skin temperature and thermal response can rise to several issues, such as a lack of interpretability in the mechanisms which influence the predictions. Moreover, black-box models may encounter difficulties in generalizing to different scenarios. These OCC strategies are capable to unravel people’s comfort preferences based on analytical information, unlocking an uncertain point in human centred studios, the dependency on personal judgments of occupants. 1.3 Building energy performance tools implementing personal comfort models The integration of PCMs in BEPS tools was explored by researchers and software developers to incorporate more accurate comfort models into building simulation tools, better representing the physiological response of occupants, as well as to assess the impact of OCC strategies on the building energy use [35]. Commonly used commercial tools, such as EnergyPlus, IDA ICE, DesignBuilder, and OpenStudio, TRNSYS, incorporate personal comfort models to provide more realistic assessments of occupant comfort [36]. Most comfort models implemented in commercial BEPS are based on conventional Fanger’s theory or on adaptive approaches implemented in standards [37]. The only exception is represented by Design Builder, which implements additional approaches, such as the Pierce and the KSU ones [38]. The integration of PCM in commercial BEPS tool may require additional development and customization. Moreover, PCM can be computationally demanding, particularly when considering dynamic occupant responses and real-time interactions with occupied building. This can result in longer simulation times and makes the models highly sensitive to assumptions, complexity and input data quality [39]. To address these issues, especially with respect to flexibility, PCM are now being developed and implemented into in-house BEPS tools. These tools offer greater flexibility and customization options compared to widely used commercial software, and they also allows for implementing custom or advanced control algorithms for specific application [40]. In-house BEPS tools allow researchers to tailor the simulation environment to their specific needs, to fine-tune the model to match specific research objective or indoor spaces scenarios, and to test and prototype new comfort models and update theme [13]. The PCM integration in BEPS tools, commercial or in-house, comes with several challenges basically linked to i) the way the dynamic response of the human body to environmental conditions is modelled [11], ii) the need for detailed occupant data, also necessary for calibration and validation purposes [41]. The first one can be approached integrating PCM in BEPS tools to add complexity to the simulation process. Specifically, diverse, simple, and complex, methods for the assessment of the modelling of the effective human body thermal adaptation and the actual perceived comfort can be available in the literature [42]. Among these, numerous studies have proposed different approaches to enhance comfort and energy efficiency in buildings through simulations and optimization methods, many still relying on Fanger’s theory [43,44]. Some investigations have explored alternative methods to improve comfort and energy efficiency. Anand et al. [45] presents a simplified tool for designing building layouts based on thermal comfort simulations, yet it also depends on PMV as the decision variable. Another research effort proposes an enhancement to Rohles’ equation to account for different clothing thermal insulation ranges [46], while a different study [47] develops a meta-data model for optimizing building envelope design with a balance between energy-savings and thermal comfort. Moreover, researchers have delved into data-driven models for thermal comfort and indoor air quality perception [48]. Additionally, a model-free reinforcement learning algorithm is employed in another study [49] to optimize HVAC systems based on the thermal sensation state and CO2 concentrations in indoor space. Lei et al. [50] developed a deep reinforcement learning model that integrates personalized thermal comfort and occupants’ presence, followed by a pre-train in a virtual space and an online deployment in real office space. The model guarantee about 10 % improvement of thermal acceptability and around 15 % of reduction in cooling energy use. Despite the diversity of analyses conducted, all these works, including those with in-house developed BEPS, continue to rely on standard comfort approaches. A good BEPS tool integrating PCM must be capable to simulate the human comfort depending on various factors, physiological and environmental, including air temperature, humidity, air velocity, clothing insulation, metabolic rate, and radiant temperature. Capturing the interactions between these factors is essential for realistic comfort modelling and reliable results [51]. Simultaneously, as environmental conditions and occupant behaviour evolve, the human body’s comfort perception also changes over time. To ensure accurate building energy performance simulations, it is crucial for advanced tools to capture the dynamic nature of thermal comfort. These tools should be capable of considering two essential factors: i) individual variability in human comfort perception, accounting for diverse needs and preferences based on factors such as age, sex, and culture, and ii) localized comfort, which allows for optimizing indoor air control strategies, system component sizing, and operation [52]. Concerning the second class of challenges, it is worth noticing that the need of data such as activity patterns, metabolic rates, etc., are often unknown and, additionally, considered as static assumptions / parameters for dynamic simulation purposes. For validation and calibration aims, extensive data collection and controlled experiments to ensure model’s accuracy and reliability are not easily available [53]. Moreover, since the accuracy of PCM can vary based on the model’s complexity and the quality of input data, developed models may not fully capture individual variations in comfort preferences and physiological responses due to low accuracy. Validating and calibrating personal comfort models against real-world data and human subject experiments is essential to ensure their accuracy and reliability, whereas gathering high quality data can be challenging and resource-intensive [15]. From this point of view, recent advances in sensing technologies, data analytics, and computational methods are facilitating more accurate and realistic representations of occupants’ comfort [54]. Nevertheless, the research in this field continues and the integration of personal comfort models in building simulations is still an on-going research area, that clearly holds great promise for the energy-efficient building design and operation and for creating occupant-centric and comfortable indoor environments [55]. 2 Research objectives and contributions Several scientific literatures pointed out the dependency of the thermal comfort sensation on the action of thermoregulatory systems, which in turn influence on dynamic changes in physiological information. Considering the limitations presented in classical thermal comfort models, to merge physiological and environmental data for describing analytically thermal preferences and then controlling building systems can lead to energy savings and improvement of thermal comfort satisfaction. More than that, it is necessary to start to contemplate environmental domains not in an isolate approach, but in multi-domain analysis, appealing to the complexity of human sensation of their surroundings. Buildings’ operation and management process is facilitated by the integration of different sensing technologies, promoted by the Internet of Things (IoT) connectivity, finding place in the new challenges rose for human liveability in urban environments. Based on the information presented above, the objective of this study is to develop an Occupant-Centric Control system that focuses on both thermal and air quality comfort domains. This system is based on a dynamic human body simulation model, which utilizes physiological signals from individuals and environmental data to simulate the body’s response and understand thermal sensation under various conditions and metabolic rates. The collection of physiological signals is done using non-intrusive sensors, allowing occupants to freely engage in activities. To this aim, the developed simulation model addresses the limitations of traditional thermal comfort models, which rely on steady-state assumptions to define satisfaction guidelines. To ensure the reliability of the model, a validation process was conducted through a multi-domain experimental campaign taking place in the NEXT, a test room facility designed to realise highly controlled environmental conditions, at the University of Perugia. The developed model is implemented into an in-house BEPS tool to be used for the design of HVAC controls and setting strategies for more occupant centric and energy efficient buildings. The tool enables a comprehensive analysis of the interaction between humans and the built environment, facilitating the establishment of optimal setpoint values for the HVAC system in terms of temperature, relative humidity, and ventilation rate. Overall, the study aims to address the interaction between the indoor environment, the human body, and the HVAC system, as well as to bridge the gap between human demands and the built environment by turning occupant comfort criteria into actual environmental conditions. The primary contributions of this study can be outlined as follows: • Development of a highly flexible Personal Comfort Model (PCM) capable of predicting thermal sensations and CO2 intakes of occupants, with the ability to adapt to diverse individual characteristics. • Implementation of the PCM within DETECt, an in-house Building Energy Performance Simulation (BEPS) tool developed by the University of Naples Federico II [56,57]. This integration enables comprehensive energy analyses, taking into account the impact of occupants’ subjective comfort preferences. • Introduction of a multi-level non-linear programming optimization procedure, aimed at determining optimal thermo-hygrometric setpoint conditions. The objective is to minimize space heating and cooling requirements, while addressing multi-domain comfort concerns related to thermal sensations, skin temperature, and perception of air quality. • Adoption of a Model Predictive Control (MPC) strategy for HVAC system management, designed to attain the determined setpoints and ensure mechanical ventilation while achieving economic savings. The MPC strategy involves a non-linearly constrained optimization problem, manipulating supply air enthalpy and mass flow variables while adhering to technological limitations and minimum air quality requirements. Overall, this study aims to enhance our understanding of occupant comfort by developing an advanced control system that considers both thermal and air quality factors. By utilizing a dynamic human body simulation model and real experimental data, this research contributes to the optimization of HVAC control strategies for smart buildings. 3 Methodology A holistic approach for the design and operation of building systems is developed to provide occupants’ comfort and energy saving by considering the dynamics of indoor spaces conditions and the human perception and adaptation. To reach this goal, the proposed methodology follows several steps: i) development of a HVAC control logic based on a model predictive control (MPC) approach; it aims at regulating key system parameters such as mass flow, temperature, and humidity of the treated supply air. This will allow the achievement of desired reference conditions while ensuring energy savings. ii) implementation of a multi-level nonlinear programming (MLNLP) optimization process, within the MPC algorithm, used to determine the thermo-hygrometric setpoints for the occupied space. This optimization process seeks to maximize occupant comfort while minimizing energy consumption. iii) Implementation of previous algorithms in an in-house BEPS tool with an appropriate human body thermal model for estimating comfort requirements based on occupants’ dynamic physiological response. Fig. 1 provides a detailed overview of the study framework, illustrating the various components and their interconnections. By employing this methodology, the performance of HVAC systems is enhanced by ensuring that occupants experience optimal thermal comfort and air quality and focusing on efficient building operations. Fig. 1 illustrates the workflow of the developed methodology which was developed in Matlab R2022b version. The optimization procedure for evaluating the setpoints is iterated at regular intervals, matching the control horizon of the MPC controller for the HVAC system. This iterative process generates outputs, specifically the optimal setpoint of indoor air temperature and relative humidity, for the entire prediction horizon. These outputs are then utilized to enhance the control of building systems. By incorporating both the thermal model of the human body and the energy model of the building, a comprehensive forecast of the variables that greatly impact the optimization problem under investigation is achieved. This approach enables a more precise and effective management of the building's environment. The physical model of the building enables the dynamic evaluation of thermodynamic quantities that impact the energy requirements ( Q ̇ HVAC ) of the internal space and occupant well-being. These quantities include the temperatures of the air node and envelope surfaces, as well as heat transfer resulting from transmission and radiative exchanges, such as solar and long-wave radiation. The physiological model of the occupants facilitates the prediction of their skin temperature (Tskin ), and CO2 generation rate which is influenced by thermal interactions with the surrounding environment and controlled by thermoregulatory mechanisms. After predicting the values of interest for the subsequent time interval, the optimization problem of the MLNLP type is performed to determine the optimal solutions for the decision variables. The resulting MLNLP outputs serve as reference values for the MPC regulation of the system. The primary objective of MPC is to minimize the costs associated with HVAC system operation by adjusting the manipulated variables, specifically the enthalpy and flow rate of the supply air. Therefore, by ensuring that these values comply with the energy balance of the conditioned space, overall costs related to the fan and heat pump are reduced. In this case as well, the energy model of the building is utilized as MPC predictor model to make forecasts of the system’s state variables. Finally, this process is repeated at every control horizon, taking into account the updated state variables of the building-occupant-plant system based on the regulations made in the previous time step. 3.1 Building energy model DETECt, an in-house BEPS tool, was created to achieve flexibility in designing and optimizing custom or advanced control algorithms, new building envelope integrated technologies, new or not yet commercialized materials/technology, and novel operating energy saving techniques [56]. The tool, developed in-house by the Federico II University, it is meant to be used in this study to estimate the thermal demands of the indoor space and building state variables for the proposed HVAC control strategy. The model on which the tool is based relies on the finite difference method, by considering the thermal domain as one dimensional. More specifically, it implements a high order resistive-capacitive (RC) thermal network, obtained by distributed parameters, that enables the calculation of both the internal surfaces' temperatures as well as the mean radiant temperature Tmr . Equation (1) represents the differential equation of the RC thermal network used to assess the thermal load of the structure and the temporal evolution of the air node properties [56]: (1) C air d T air dt = ∑ i = 1 N T in , i - T air R in , i conv + Q ̇ gain , s e n s + m ̇ vent c p T out - T air ± Q ̇ HVAC , s e n s Where Cair is the internal air node's thermal capacity and the terms to the right of Eq. (1) stand for the thermal power fluxes that the air temperature node Tair exchanges with the surroundings. The first term describes the energy transmitted due to convection between the thermal nodes of Tin,i (i.e., the interior surface of the i-th wall of the building envelope) and Tair , and function of Rin,i convective thermal resistance. It can be noted that the radiative heat exchanges with the corresponding surrounding walls and the solar gains from transparent components were taken into consideration while calculating Tin,i [58]. The thermal sources of people, lights, and equipment are also regarded as Q ̇ gain , s e n s among the thermal inputs of the inside zone. The mass flow rate m ̇ vent of outside air and the outside temperature Tout affect the sensible ventilation heat load. Finally, Q ̇ HVAC , s e n s reflects the thermal power required to balance the flows that weigh on the thermal zone and cause the internal temperature Tin to deviate from the setpoint temperature. In addition, the latent thermal power Q ̇ HVAC , l a t is calculated in Eq. (2): (2) μ in d ω in dt = m ̇ w , g a i n + m ̇ vent ω out - ω in Q ̇ HVAC , l a t t = Δ h vs · μ in ω in t - ω sp t Where μin is the indoor dry air mass, ωout and ωin are the outdoor and indoor air specific humidity, respectively. The right side of the first equation represents the inlet water vapour mass flow rate due to occupants and ventilation. Consequently, the latent thermal power Q ̇ HVAC , l a t is evaluated as a function of water latent evaporation heat Δhvs and the difference between ωin and ωsp which is the setpoint value of specific humidity. The tool needs the following inputs to run energy simulations: the climate-relevant location, the shape and orientation of the building, the thermophysical characteristics of the materials, the internal heat gain schedules, the building air change profile, and the setpoint temperature and humidity. More details, also concerning the tool experimental validation, are reported in [59]. 3.2 Human body thermal model This section outlines the fundamental elements of the proposed human body thermal model, which employs a multi-node thermal approach [60], for the easily integration in DETECt. The model captures the dynamic physiological response and energetic interactions between the human body and the building, accommodating non-steady-state conditions. The human body is represented (Fig. 2 ) by a system of concentric cylindrical layers (core, muscle, fat, and skin [15]), interconnected by ducts simulating the circulatory system. Within this model, convective heat exchange occurs through blood flow within the organic tissues of the human body. The model implementation in the dynamic building energy performance simulation tool previously is described hereinafter. 3.2.1 Human body discretization procedure To achieve the objectives of the proposed methodology, a one-dimensional transient analysis is employed to resolve the temperature field distribution within the human body. This requires capturing the temporal variations of skin temperature, thermal sensation, and thermal heat gain. The geometrical and thermodynamic properties of the human body are derived from Fiala’s [15] work, with specific values outlined in Table 1 . The radius of each cylindrical layers in the physiological thermal model (ri ) is calculated as a weighted average of the 16 cylinders considered in Fiala’s model, described in Equation (3). (3) r i = ∑ i = 1 4 ∑ j = 1 s r i , j · V i , j V i , t o t / ∑ i = 1 4 ∑ j = 1 s V i , j V i , t o t h e i g h t = A s k i n 2 · π · r s k i n The height of the cylinder, determined by the skin surface area (Askin ) and the radius of the skin layer (rskin ), is crucial for accurately estimating the overall shape of the human body. While this simplified representation assumes a single cylinder, it is sufficient for the purposes of this study, as it does not significantly affect the accuracy of the results. 3.2.2 Heat transfer within the tissues The discretized human body is further modelled using a resistive-capacitive (RC) thermal network [61], as shown in Fig. 2. This network describes the heat dissipation mechanisms occurring within the human body. A bio-physiological partial differential equation governs the transfer of heat, considering parameters such as radial temperature gradients, metabolic heat production, blood circulation, and environmental heat exchange. (4) ρ body · c p , b o d y k body ∂ T ∂ t = 1 r d dr r dT dr + MR · ρ inside k inside × V inside V body + + Q ̇ ev k inside · V body + m ̇ blood · c p , b l o o d k inside · V body × T inside - T skin The differential equation incorporates diverse factors to determine space–time temperature variation, including the radius (r), net metabolic rate (MR), densities (ρ), thermal conductivities (k), heat capacitance (cp ) and volumes (V) of the different layers. Additionally, it accounts for the heat exchanged due to convection with blood perfusion, and latent heat of vaporization Q ̇ ev related to sweating rate. Note that the core and muscle layers are merged into a single layer called inside characterized by the presence of thermal generation. The generation term of the differential equation is represented by MR. The rate of metabolic heat accumulated in core and muscle layers (MR) can be estimated as the difference between the production of metabolic energy (M) and mechanical work (W), as: (5) MR = M - W = C E O 2 · V ̇ O 2 mass × 1 - η V ̇ O 2 = 0.3 × H R - 16.44 × m a s s × 10 - 3 / 60 Where η is the energy efficiency of the human body [15]. The metabolic rate is proportional to the rate of oxygen consumption ( V ̇ O 2 ) and to the caloric equivalent per litre of oxygen consumed (CEO2 ). The volume of oxygen breathed by a person ( V ̇ O 2 ) is assessed with the formulation provided by Nelson’s work [62] in function of body weight and heart rate (HR). The heat exchange through blood circulation is influenced by the temperature difference between adjacent bloodstreams, blood perfusion, and heat capacitance (see Table 1). In this model, the blood temperature is assumed to be equal to the temperature of the corresponding body layer.
