The blood perfusion rate is then determined using the following formula: (7) m ̇ blood = 6.3 + 200 · C R SIG 1 + 0.5 · ( - S K SIG ) × 1 3600 The evaporative heat loss from the skin depends on the difference between the water vapor pressure at the skin and the water vapor pressure in the indoor air, as well as the amount of moisture on the skin (w) and the evaporative resistance (Rev ). This relationship is given by Equation (8): (8) Q ̇ ev = w · p skin - p va / R ev R ev = 1 / k c · A skin m ̇ sw = 4.7 · 10 ( - 5 ) · B SIG · e ( S K SIG / 10.7 ) The evaporative resistance (Rev ) is determined by the evaporative exchange coefficient (kc ) and Askin . Here, the term w is evaluated in function of m ̇ sw that represents the sweat flow rate. It is determined based on the body signal (BSIG ) and the skin signal (SKSIG ) according to the reference work of Kaynakli and Kilic [64]. The boundary conditions to solve the differential equation are represented by the heat exchanged with the environment. (9) Q ̇ bound = γ global · f cl · A skin · T cl - T op T cl = T skin - I cl · 0.155 Q ̇ cl / A skin Where Tcl is the temperature of the clothing layer, and Icl is the clothing resistance according to ASHRAE standards [64]. Here, fcl is the enhancement factor of the skin surface of the human body due to clothing, Top is the operative temperature, and γglobal is the global heat transfer coefficient linked to the convection and radiation terms. Details about the heat transfer coefficients are reported in [13]. Once the boundary and initial conditions are defined, the implicit finite volume numerical method is adopted for solving the differential bio-physiological equation (Equation (4)). 3.2.3 CO2 generation rates In order to assess the impact of indoor air quality (IAQ) on human body response and HVAC operation, the generation rates of CO2 by occupants are considered, described in Equation (10): (10) V ̇ C O 2 = V ̇ O 2 × R Q CO2 concentrations serve as an indicator of IAQ and the adequacy of outdoor air ventilation. The rate of CO2 generation ( V ̇ C O 2 ) per person is determined by the respiratory quotient (RQ), which represents the ratio of CO2 production rate to oxygen consumption rate. In this model, an RQ value of 0.85 is assumed, considering a typical diet [63]. The simulation model assumes uniform CO2 distribution within indoor spaces. 3.3 MLNLP optimization for indoor setpoint evaluation For the determination of thermo-hygrometric setpoints in the occupied space, a multi-level nonlinear programming (MLNLP) optimization procedure was employed. Fig. 3 shows a schematization of the optimization problem investigated, identifying the constrained spaces and the search space for the optimal solution. The decision variables x, which are subject to optimization, include the temperature Tair,ref and relative humidity RHair,ref of the air within the indoor space. The optimization problem is defined as follows: (11) min x Q ̇ HVAC = f ( x ) s . t . x ( 1 ) = T air , r e f x ( 2 ) = R H air , r e f - 0.5 ≤ P M V ∗ ≤ 0.5 P I A Q ≤ 1 The main objective is to minimize the thermal energy demand for space heating and cooling, denoted as Q ̇ HVAC . To assess individual thermal sensation accurately, the comfort index PMV* (modified version of the Fanger comfort index [65]) takes into account the skin temperature Tskin as a significant parameter. This allows for the evaluation of the first constraint space for the decision variables, ensuring they fall within acceptable ranges. PMV* can be expressed as described in Equation (12): (12) PM V * = 0.0303 e 0.036 M + 0.028 × ( M W ) - 3 . 05 × 10 - 3 5733 - 6 . 99 ( M W ) - x ( 2 ) p v , s a t + - 0 . 42 [ ( M W ) - 58 . 15 ] - 1 . 7 × 10 - 5 M ( 5867 - x ( 2 ) p v , s a t ) + - 0 . 0014 M ( 34 - x ( 1 ) ) - 3 . 96 × 10 - 8 × × f c l [ ( T c l + 273 ) 4 - ( T m r + 273 ) 4 ] - f c l ( γ c , f + γ c , n ) ( T c l + x ( 1 ) ) Here, M and MW represent the energy quantity associated with the metabolic rate and mechanical work performed by the occupant. The clothing temperature Tcl is dependent on Tskin , while the heat exchange surface increase factor fcl estimates the influence of clothing on the occupant's heat exchange with the surrounding environment. The saturation pressure of vapour pv,sat , heat transfer coefficients γc,f and γc,n , and the mean radiant temperature Tmr are used to evaluate the rates of latent, convective, and radiative heat transfer, which impact the occupant's thermal perception. Subsequently, the PIAQ [66] is employed to define the second constraint space, linked to a new comfort domain. It quantifies the levels of air quality perception experienced by occupants in indoor environments. This perception is influenced by various environmental factors. Fanger [67,68] demonstrated a strong correlation between PIAQ and indoor air temperature and humidity. His experiments involved exposing occupants to a spectrum of indoor environments, ranging from clean to polluted (e.g., environments with factors such as wall paint, carpet, floor detergents, etc.). These experiments help to observe how air enthalpy can significantly impact the perception of air quality, even in settings with strong odors. This domain requires values of PIAQ lower than 1 decipol to ensure high acceptability (ACC) of air quality and a percentage of dissatisfied (PD) which is lower than 15 %. The ACC and PD can be evaluated as reported in Equation (13): (13) ACC = - 0.0143 h air , r e f + 0.895 P D = exp ( - 0.18 - 5.28 · A C C ) 1 + exp ( - 0.18 - 5.28 · A C C ) · 100 Here, hair,ref represents the enthalpy of the air setpoint, which is a function of the decision variables in the optimization problem. 3.4 MPC for HVAC operation The optimization of HVAC system operation is crucial to achieve the desired thermo-hygrometric conditions while minimizing operating costs. In this regard, a MPC strategy has been developed to optimize the manipulated variables xmv , specifically the supply air enthalpy ( h air , s ) and flow rate ( m ̇ air , s ). This allows for finding the optimal trade-off between fan energy consumption due to pressure drop balancing and the heat pump's cooling and heating requests. The use of MPC in HVAC systems offers several advantages over traditional control strategies. MPC considers the system dynamics and predicts future behaviour, enabling better response to changing environmental conditions and load variations, resulting in improved energy efficiency and occupant comfort [69]. The prediction of the building-occupant-plant system’s state variables is obtained by means of the DETECt tool, by adopting the mathematical models described in the previous subsections. This includes the assessment of surface and air node temperatures, as well as the Q ̇ HVAC thermal load, while accounting for variations in external climatic conditions and internal energy inputs. Incorporating these models enhances the accuracy of predictions and enables proactive adjustment of setpoints and control actions. The selection of the control horizon Γ and prediction horizon Λ in MPC is crucial for achieving desired system performance. The control horizon determines the length of sample time ts over which control actions are computed, while the prediction horizon defines the duration for which future system behaviour is predicted. These horizons are carefully chosen based on system dynamics, time delays, and computational complexity considerations. The analysed HVAC system is an air handling unit equipped with cooling and heating coils respectively for dehumidification and relative humidity control of indoor space during the cooling season. In the heating season, heating coils and a liquid humidifier are used. The coefficient of performance (COP) for the heat pump is calculated using the UNI-TS 11300 method, considering partial load operation. (14) CO P PLR = C O P nom × 1 - C d · 1 - Q ̇ HVAC Q ̇ nom , H P Considering the Cd coefficient equal to 0.25 as referred to air/air heat pumps. To evaluate fan energy consumption, pressure drops are calculated based on flow properties (air velocity vair and density ρair ). (15) Δ p HVAC = f duct ρ air L duct v air 2 2 D h , d u c t + K coil ρ air v air 2 2 + K filter ρ air v air 2 2 Where the first term on the right of the equation represents the pressure drop distributed through the ducts and depends on its geometric (hydraulic diameter Dh,duct and length Lduct ) and construction characteristics which influence the friction factor fduct . The remaining two terms express the concentrated pressure drops due to the main components of the system, coils, and filters. Kcoil and Kfilter express the resistance coefficients that depend on the construction characteristics of the components. 3.4.1 MPC optimization problem For the MPC a constrained nonlinear optimization technique is used. The implemented algorithm is designed to iteratively search for the optimal control inputs while satisfying specified constraints. Specifically, an interior-point algorithm is implemented to find the solution within a feasible region defined by the constraints and to iteratively adjust the control inputs to minimize a cost function by taking into account both control objectives and system constraints. Thus, the algorithm is able to systematically optimize control inputs in real-time, while considering both current system states and future predictions, allowing us to make decisions that balance performance and constraints. Specifically, the cost function (JHVAC ) to be minimized is evaluated as follows. (16) m i n x m v J H V A C = ∫ t t + Λ x m v 1 x m v 2 - h a i r , e x t C O P P L R + ∫ t t + Λ x m v 1 / ρ a i r , s · Δ p H V A C η F A N · c e l s . t . x m v 1 = m ̇ a i r , s x m v 2 = h a i r , s The cost function equation represents the cumulative sum of costs over the prediction horizon Λ. It is influenced by the efficiencies of the heat pumps and fans (ηFAN and COPPLR ) as well as the unitary electrical costs (cel ). The manipulated variables, h air , s and m ̇ air , s , are determined subject to the following conditions: (17) x mv 1 · x mv 2 = x mv 1 · h air , i n + Q ̇ HVAC x mv 1 ∈ m ̇ air , min = f V ̇ C O 2 ; m ̇ air , max = f V ̇ fan , max x mv 2 ∈ h air , n o m , c c ; min h air , e x t ; h air , i n → c o o l i n g x mv 2 ∈ max h air , e x t ; h air , i n ; h air , n o m , h c → h e a t i n g The first nonlinear equation ensures the heat balance in the building's control volume. Q ̇ HVAC is assumed negative for cooling requests and positive for heating requests. The second condition defines lower and upper limits for the air mass flow processed by the air handling unit. The minimum value depends on the occupant's V ̇ C O 2 generation rate, estimated using the human body model. The upper limit is determined by the’fan's maximum range constraints. The third and fourth conditions set the lower and upper limits for hair,s during cooling and heating requests. For cooling, hair,s falls between the minimum enthalpy from the cooling coil (hair,nom,cc ) and the minimum value between hair,in and hair,ext . Conversely, for heating, hair,s falls between the maximum value of the two previous quantities and the maximum achievable hair,nom,hc from the heating coil. The xmv variables are normalized to facilitate the search for the optimal solution since they have different orders of magnitude. Once the constrained optimization problem is solved, the xmv values that minimize the cost function for all prediction horizon moves are obtained. Only the moves within the control horizon will be implemented. By utilizing this control strategy, the HVAC system can optimize its operation and minimize costs while achieving the desired thermo-hygrometric conditions. 4 Experimental setup An experimental procedure was carried out to validate the proposed human-physiological simulation model. Tests were conducted in a test room facility to gather data of subjects in different activity levels and with different personal intrinsic characteristics, such as gender and Body Mass Index (BMI). The information collected was used as input for the model reliability verification. The subsequent sections provided comprehensive descriptions regarding the methodology, the test room, and the participants involved. 4.1 NEXT.ROOM: targeting human-centric and multi-domain investigation The NEXT.ROOM is a highly controlled environment located inside the Environmental Applied Physics Lab, at the Engineering campus of the University of Perugia, in central Italy [70]. The test room was constructed specifically to perform multi-disciplinary and multi-domain studies within the human well-being scope. To this end, the installed systems allow to reproduce different environmental conditions and stimuli, accordingly to the research purposes. The facility (Fig. 4) was built entirely with dry technologies, easily enabling adaptation if required. Regarding the technical systems, a radiant system serving all the NEXT.ROOM surfaces and a mechanical ventilation and air-conditioning (HVAC) system manage the thermal domain; the lighting system is composed of four LED panels and two RGB reflectors, providing different conditions of illuminance spatial distribution and correlated colour temperature (CCT). A detailed characterization of the design and decision process, materials dimensions technical specifications of the NEXT.ROOM was provided by Vittori et al. [70]. On the other hand, a monitoring system is dedicated to gather all environmental information in the different testing scenarios. The fixed sensors enable the continuous measurement of (i) air temperature in four different (and adjustable) heights; (ii) relative humidity; (iii) superficial temperature in different surface points; (iv) air velocity; (v) CO2 concentration; (vi) globe temperature; (vii) net radiation on the three main directions; (viii) heat flux through the envelope surfaces; (ix) illuminance level. Wearable sensors are also available to monitor physiological signals such as skin temperature, Electrodermal Activity (EDA), electrocardiogram (ECG) and electroencephalography (EEG). For this study, collect data of mean radiant temperature and indoor CO2 concentration are used for model verification [71]. In other words, the monitoring data was implemented as input in the simulation model with the aim at reducing the source of discrepancy and focusing on the proposed human-body thermal model. 4.2 A study approach for assessing human physiological information To reproduce different metabolism conditions, an experimental procedure was handled with two young subjects, one male and one female. Ten-points were selected to place skin temperature sensors, following the indications of Liu et al. [72], focused on human thermal comfort studies. The iButton Hygrochron was adopted to proceed with the measurements, using a time step of one minute. The heart-rate frequency was measured through the Empatica E4 wrist band, i.e. an equipment validated by many authors investigating physiological signals to human comfort preferences modelling [73], collecting data each second. Concerning the environmental sensors, the CO2 monitoring was executed by three sensors, positioned (1) near the top discharge outlet; (2) the bottom discharge outlet; (3) in the centre of the room at the desk height. Air temperature sensors were located in the centre of the room, in different heights: 10 cm, 50 cm, 110 cm, and 170 cm. Additionally, superficial temperature sensors were located in all walls, ceiling and floor. All environmental sensors gathered data using a one-minute timestep. Fig. 4 describe the position of the sensors inside the NEXT.ROOM. Two different experiment paths were adopted, focusing on the exposure of recruited subjects to different activity conditions in two operative phases of the HVAC system. The first one (Fig. 5 ) carried out a test with a male subject for 150 min, from 9:00 AM to 11:30 AM, with a subject performing sedentary activities in a seated position, such as studying. The air velocity was set at the 4th level (maximum) during the first hour of test, and then maintained constant at the 2nd level until the end. Table 2 describes technical specifications of the HVAC system. The temperature setpoint was 21 °C at the first test hour, 24 °C in the following hours, until the end of the experiment. The conditions changes allow the model to understand the body response because of environmental fluctuations in sedentary conditions. The second procedure (Fig. 6 ) involved a female subject, in different activity levels, for 150 min, starting at the 10:00 AM. Three operative phases were comprised in the experiment: acclimatization phase, consisting of 30 min of acclimatization stage, with the subject seated in neutral conditions, the first air flow condition, that maintain all the setpoint, visual and acoustics characteristics but specifying the 2nd level of HVAC system air velocity and the second air flow condition, also keeping the acclimatization characteristics, but changing HVAC system air velocity for the 4th level. Setpoint value was maintained constant at 24 °C during the whole test, searching to follow ASHRAE 55-2020 general comfort recommendations [74]. Two activity levels were established: the first condition (light) consists in walking in a treadmill at 1.2 km/h velocity; the second condition (moderate), uses a 4 km/h velocity in the treadmill. The systems characteristics were described in Table 2 , applicable for both experiment paths. The two subjects, despite their similar age, present very different body compositions. A summary of their personal characteristics considered in the model, i.e., weight, height, clothing level etc, is given in Table 3 . 5 Proof-of-concept The proposed study seeks to analyse the potentials of the proposed PCM implemented in a BEPS tool with the aim at addressing the interaction among indoor environment - human body – HVAC system. To this aim, the proof of concept for the developed methodology involves simulating the previously described experimental tests by exploiting the thermal model of the human body and the new facility management system. The simulation aimed to verify the accuracy of the physiological model by recreating the operating conditions of the HVAC system shown in Fig. 5 and Fig. 6, specifically to evaluate the predictive performance of the model in tracking the occupant’s skin temperature. The simulation also demonstrated the flexibility of the model, as it successfully adapted to different subjects and various metabolic activity conditions in the two tests. After validation of the physiological model, the tests were further simulated using the proposed system management methodology to evaluate its impact on occupant comfort and energy consumption, and a comparison with the reference scenario was provided. The reference scenario is rooted in real-world, measured data from experimental tests, while the proposed scenario is evaluated with a simulation. However, the simulation aspect involves predicting how occupants' physiological properties would behave under different environmental conditions based on the same characteristics of the subjects from the reference scenario (e.g., body weight, skin surface, metabolic rate, etc.). As previously mentioned, the proposed scenario involved determining the thermo-hygrometric setpoints (Table 4 ) through an MLNLP optimization procedure, aimed at minimizing thermal energy demands for space heating and cooling while maximizing thermal comfort and air quality perception. The HVAC system was then managed through an MPC control strategy, optimizing its operation by manipulating the mass flow rate and thermodynamic properties of the air supplied to the room. The MPC controller's choice of mass flow rate ensured the minimum ventilation rate necessary for efficient CO2 removal in the room, estimated based on the occupant’s CO2 generation rate. Meanwhile, the enthalpy of the air delivery flow was adjusted to comply with the technological limits of the HVAC system. For the MPC controller’s characteristics, a control horizon of 15 min was chosen, considering the transient behaviour of the HVAC system, and a prediction horizon of 60 min (equal to 4 control horizons) was used (Table 4). To evaluate the JHVAC cost function, a unit cost of electricity (cel ) value of 0.22 cents [75] per electric kilowatt-hour was considered. This allowed the MPC controller to optimize the HVAC system’s performance efficiently, balancing energy consumption and occupant comfort. The simulations demonstrated the potential effectiveness of the proposed methodology in achieving energy savings and enhancing indoor thermal comfort while considering occupants’ specific needs and dynamic environmental conditions. After the simulations, the observed and simulated PMV* and PD percentages were compared, as well as the energy use for each scenario. 6 Results 6.1 Accuracy of the physiological thermal model The tests were carried out in 2022 on September 15th of 2021 for subject 1 and on October 17th of 2022 for subject 2, both with the same 150 min of duration. Table 3 provides data relative to the investigated subjects (weight, height, clothes); their consent for personal data was previously obtained. Fig. 7 shows the trends of the air temperature measured near the workstation of the investigated subjects, and the average radiant temperature Tmr measured by the globe-thermometer. Additionally, the trends of air velocities measured near the workstation are shown. Fig. 7 refers to a constant value of indoor air relative humidity within the room (equals to 50 %). To assess the accuracy of the model, the simulated skin temperature (Tskin,evaluated ) is compared with the measured skin temperature (Tskin,measured ) for both subjects (subject 1 and subject 2) during the test period. The comparison is reported in Fig. 8 left) for subject 1 and subject 2 Fig. 8 right). In the Fig. 8, the two green lines relative to Upper and Lower limits refer to a comparison band set between Tskin,measured + 0.7 °C and Tskin,measured – 0.7 °C. This error band is related to a temperature deviation which involves error bands of ±3 %. Please note that the heart rate is equivalent to the average heart rate, which is measured over the same interval of skin temperature sampling. The results of both tests show a strong agreement between the simulation and experimental data, indicating that the developed model is reliable and suitable for conducting thermal comfort and building energy performance analyses based on the dynamic thermal sensation of occupants. It is worth mentioning that, in the case of subject 2 engaging in light and moderate activities, the model demonstrates improved performance when activity levels change. However, there is a slight delay in the simulation model’s ability to capture the impact of activity levels at the beginning of the simulation. This delay occurs because the initial background data conditions, such as the environment and subjects, are essential for the training process. Despite this initial delay, the model maintains its accuracy throughout the main duration of the occupation. When considering longer occupation times, the initial conditions may have a negligible influence on the occupant’ thermal sensation. Therefore, they can be safely disregarded without significantly affecting the overall validity of the model's predictions. It is important to note that the first phase of the experiment is typically an acclimatization phase. The findings therefore demonstrate the reliability and suitability of the developed model for analysing thermal comfort and building energy performance based on occupant' dynamic thermal sensation. The model's performance is particularly notable when activity levels change, and any initial delay in capturing the impact of activity levels is outweighed by the model's accuracy during the main duration of the occupation. Fig. 9 shows for each test (Fig. 9left for the 1st test, Fig. 9right for the 2nd test), the simulated temperatures of the organic tissues of the two subjects. Different temperatures are observed due to the dynamism of thermoregulatory system and diverse activity levels. Fig. 10 compares the investigated subjects’ body surface temperature, Tskin , simulated (y-axis) and measured (x-axis), by considering their deviations for the considered sampling interval. Almost all simulation results are included into the error band range of ±3 % (red dashed lines) for both tests, whereas in test 2 a larger error is observed during the initial occupation time intervals. The 97 % and 84 % of simulation results (Tskin,evaluated ), respectively for test 1 and test 2, are included in the confidence interval ±2 % (green dashed lines) and the 66 % (test 1) and 79 % (test 2) in the narrower interval given by ±1 % (orange dashed lines). To assess the model's response more comprehensively, two statistical indices, namely the Pearson index (p) and the relative percentage error, were utilized. The Pearson index, which ranges from −1 to 1, provides a measure of the match between the simulated and experimental values. A value close to 1 indicates a strong agreement between the two datasets (see Fig. 10a and b). In Fig. 10c, a boxplot representation illustrates the distribution of relative percentage errors resulting from the comparison. The orange diamonds represent the average error, which is found to be approximately 1 % for both tests. For the first test, the boxplot shows that the median value aligns closely with the average value, and the Interquartile Range (IQR) is confined within 2 %. In contrast, for the second test, the relative percentage errors predominantly gather around negative values, indicating an underestimation of the simulated values. The median value for this case is 0 %, suggesting a reasonably accurate representation on average. The outliers in the boxplot refer to the few data points where the deviation exceeds the 3 % error band, indicating slight discrepancies in those instances. The IAQ within the test room is plotted in Fig. 11 , focusing on test 2, characterized by diverse activity levels of the human body. Fig. 11 left) shows i) the ppm of CO2 of outside the test cell (CO2,ext , measured near the inlet vents), and ii) the ppm of CO2 inside the room, including the occupant generation (CO2,room , measured near the discharge outlets). The right axis shows the survey conducted by the occupant that could rank the indoor air quality on a scale of 1 to 7. The coloured areas refer to the ASHRAE IAQ ranges as a function of the ppm of CO2 in the environment. Finally, Fig. 11 right shows the measured and simulated CO2 production of the human body for test 2, considering the different occupant activity levels. Overall, the results confirm the accuracy and reliability of the developed physiological thermal model, making it suitable for evaluating thermal comfort and building energy performance based on occupants' dynamic thermal sensations. The IAQ analysis also demonstrates the model's ability to capture indoor air quality variations under different conditions. 6.2 Proposed HVAC control strategies This section presents the results of the related proof-of-concept study, which aims to demonstrate the advantages of an optimized HVAC control strategy in terms of both occupant comfort and energy efficiency. In this section, the effects and potential benefits of the optimized OCC control strategies implementation are checked. Utilizing the developed simulation tool, the behaviour of the HVAC system was assessed under the optimized control strategy, considering various factors such as external climate conditions, thermal properties of the building, and occupancy patterns. The results related to the MLNLP optimization problem were reported in Fig. 12. The optimization procedure was iterated for each time step, equal to the control horizon, to provide the best setpoint values for the whole prediction horizon. This process relied on the forecasting capabilities of the developed model, which enabled precise assessment of the occupant's physiological features and the building's thermodynamic properties, ensuring accurate evaluation of the output variables for successive time steps. Fig. 12 illustrates the combined criteria evaluated to determine the thermo-hygrometric setpoints (Tair,ref and RHair,ref ) for the first test, with reference to the procedure performed after four steps of the control horizon, equivalent to 60 min of occupation. The Fig. 12 top shows all possible combinations of Tair and RHair that guarantee a PMV* within the acceptable range based on the predicted Tskin of the occupant at the analysed time instant. Additionally, Fig. 12 middle further investigates all those combinations which, in addition to the first constraint condition, also comply with the ones dictated by the ACC index of perceived indoor air quality. Furthermore, Fig. 12 bottom represents the solution space by analysing the values, shown in red, of the Q ̇ HVAC objective function assumed by the achievable combinations. The optimal combination that minimizes HVAC energy demands is highlighted in green. Once the reference setpoints were selected, an MPC-type control strategy was adopted to reduce operating costs associated with the HVAC system. Fig. 13 demonstrates the MPC controller operation using the proposed scenario of test 1 as reference. The results refer to a current time instant of two steps forward of the control horizon, which corresponds to 30 min from the start of occupation. In Fig. 13 top, the trend of the manipulated variables hair,s and m ̇ air , s is reported. The grey area depicts the values assumed in the actions passed to the current instant, while the next four steps (corresponding to the duration of the prediction horizon) show the actions envisaged to minimize the JHVAC cost function. Furthermore, the result reports the action that will be implemented by the controller in the next control horizon. The manipulated variables combinations presented are essential for validating the energy balance equation applied to the control volume of the air-conditioned environment. These results are consistent with the technological limitation of the specific plant, as well as the constraints imposed by external and internal thermodynamic conditions, and the minimum ventilation rate requirements. By examining the manipulated variables, we can ensure that the energy balance equation is accurately verified within the control volume. These combinations were carefully selected to comply with the technological limitations of the plant, as well as the various thermodynamic conditions both inside and outside the system. Additionally, they meet the minimum ventilation rate requirements necessary for optimal performance. It is crucial to consider the interplay between these manipulated variables and their impact on the energy balance equation. By doing so, we can guarantee that the air-conditioned environment operates within the prescribed limits, ensuring efficient and effective functioning of the system. These results not only demonstrate compliance with the technological limits of the plant but also reflect a comprehensive understanding of the external and internal thermodynamic conditions. By carefully considering these factors, we may optimize the performance of the air-conditioning system while maintaining the required minimum ventilation rates. Moreover, Fig. 13bottom displays the value of the reference enthalpy guaranteed in previous steps and those evaluated by the MLNLP optimization procedure for subsequent steps of the prediction horizon. Additionally, the value of the JHVAC objective function in the prediction horizon resulting from optimized actions of the manipulated variables is shown. Subsequently, an energy and comfort analysis are presented for the proposed scenarios of the two simulated tests. Fig. 14 and Fig. 15 show the energy results obtained from the simulation for both tests, focusing on energy savings while ensuring occupants' comfort requests. Fig. 14 top and Fig. 15 bottom illustrate the Q ̇ HVAC thermal power requests for cooling in test 1 and heating in test 2, respectively. The green dashed line shows the dynamic trend of indoor setpoints. The reference humidity (RHair,rif ) varied between 20 % and 40 % due to constraints imposed by the ACC index of perceived indoor air quality, suggesting low humidity levels for improved air quality perception. Fig. 14 bottom and Fig. 15 bottom show instead the results relating to the electrical power required by the plant and associated with the heat pump for the heating and cooling coils operation and with the fan to move the air flows and balance the drops in pressure. These electrical requests are conditioned by the convective flux supplied in the room and shown in black dashed lines, this quantity in turn is conditioned by the hair,s and m ̇ air , s determined by the optimization performed by the MPC controller. Lastly, a comfort analysis highlights the benefits of the OCC strategy, ensuring both thermal comfort and air quality for the occupants. Fig. 16 top and Fig. 17 top show the PMV* trend, demonstrating that PMV* values fall within the acceptable ranges imposed by the index for both tests. Test 1 has PMV* values close to the maximum limit, while test 2 has values close to the lower limit, reflecting the optimization procedure's goal to ensure comfort while minimizing energy requests. Fig. 16 bottom and Fig. 17 bottom demonstrate that the PD values remain below the threshold of 15 % at each plant control step, showcasing the effectiveness of the OCC strategy in maintaining air quality at desirable levels. 6.3 Results comparison To demonstrate the benefits of the developed methodology, a complete simulation analysis was performed by comparing the reference and proposed scenarios for both tests, with a focus on comfort and energy considerations. The reference scenario involves real experimental tests conducted on the two subjects, evaluating energy consumption and comfort analysis based on the HVAC system's operating conditions, occupants' physiological response, and the thermo-hygrometric setpoints reached during the tests. This approach provided valuable insights into the actual performance of the HVAC system and its impact on occupants' comfort under real-world conditions. On the other hand, the proposed scenario represents the simulation of the same tests, but with the OCC methodology described earlier. Initially, the comparison focused on occupants' comfort perceptions in the two scenarios. The results depicted in Fig. 18 revealed that in the reference scenario for both tests, occupants experienced partial thermal discomfort, as demonstrated in the trends not entirely falling within the PMV* acceptability band. For instance, in test 1, occupants experienced thermal discomfort for 40 % of the occupation time, equivalent to 60 min. Similarly, in test 2, the discomfort was experienced for 60 % of the occupancy time, equals 90 min. These findings underscored the importance of refining the HVAC control strategy to enhance occupants' thermal comfort experience. Furthermore, Fig. 18 top shows that the air quality perception discomfort levels, i.e., out of the +0.5 – −0.5 range, exceed the threshold value of 15 % for 90 % of the occupancy time in the same reference scenario. These findings reveal flaws in the reference HVAC operation, that needs to be addressed further. On the other hand, Fig. 18 bottom provides insight into the PD index percentages for the evaluation of air quality perception in test 2. In the reference scenario, the occupant experienced discomfort for only 40 % of the occupation time, showing that air quality was rather well-maintained. Overall, the proposed scenario ensured thermal comfort and air quality perception for both tests for the entire occupation time. The simulation findings demonstrate that, to maintain a comfortable indoor environment for the occupants, the HVAC control strategy could be optimized by using the developed OCC technique, The comparison analysis examined the thermal energy requests for heating and cooling in both scenarios, as depicted in Fig. 19. Notably, the proposed methodology achieved significant energy savings. In test 1, focused on cooling needs, the optimization strategy for determining thermo-hygrometric setpoints led to a 3.7 % reduction in thermal energy consumption (see Table 5). By suitably adjusting cooling setpoints based on occupants' requirements and predicted thermal dynamics, unnecessary energy usage was minimized while ensuring comfort. Furthermore, the MPC control strategy, as demonstrated in Fig. 19top, played a vital role in further reducing energy consumption. By dynamically optimizing HVAC parameters, such as fan speed and cooling/heating intensity, the MPC controller achieved a substantial 12.8 % reduction in total electricity consumed compared to the reference scenario, equivalent to 0.33 kWh (see Table 5). In test 2, Fig. 19bottom revealed that the OCC methodology resulted in 20 % thermal energy savings for heating compared to the reference scenario, accomplished by fine-tuning heating setpoints based on predicted thermal conditions and occupants' activities. Moreover, the HVAC control strategy, depicted in Fig. 19b, achieved a notable 7.8 % reduction in energy consumption compared to the reference scenario (see Table 5). This significant reduction highlighted the potential of the OCC approach for optimizing HVAC system performance and minimizing operational costs. In conclusion, the comparative analysis has emphasized the significant advantages of the developed OCC methodology in relation to occupant comfort and energy conservation. Through the efficient utilization of predictive models and intelligent control algorithms, the OCC strategy has enabled the HVAC system to dynamically respond to the needs of occupants, thereby creating an environment that is both comfortable and energy efficient. These promising results strongly advocate for the widespread implementation of advanced control strategies in HVAC systems, as they not only enhance the well-being of occupants but also promote sustainable practices within buildings. 7 Discussion International standards, based on classical comfort models, often establish fixed conditions to reach indoor comfort conditions, assuming steady-state conditions that do not contemplate people’s thermal adaptation. Specifically, CIBSE [76], ASHRAE 55 [74] and EN ISO 7730 [77] determines 21–23 °C, 21.5–24 °C and 20–26 °C as comfortable temperatures, respectively. The physiological thermal model proposed in this study takes into consideration personal data in different conditions, collected through experimental testing and creating personalized settings to improve liveability in the built environment, investigating thermal and air quality domains, while reducing energy use. Simulation results concerning the reliability and performance of the proposed the physiological thermal model shows that the lower performance observed during the initial simulated steps highlights the importance of the acclimatization phase in test room experiments. Participants need to adapt to the indoor conditions and to adjust their physiological responses to the test settings. This acclimatization phase also gives initial information to properly train the model and establish a Baseline Metabolic Rate (BMR) [18], which can adapt to new conditions, even with varying activity levels and other physiological data as input. Moreover, the physiological data was gathered through non-invasive wearable sensors, allowing the collection of higher quantity of information and during different types of situations and conditions, expanding the model capacity. The high potential of wearable sensors to monitoring in experimental tests or in a long-term basis was explored in countless research works [78], indicated as a trend for research studies tools. By utilizing the proposed simulation and optimization tool, capable of capturing the relationships of the trinomen indoor environment - human body – HVAC system, simulation findings concerning the comparison of observed and predicted results revealed that it is indeed possible to reduce energy consumption while simultaneously improving occupant comfort. The MPC strategy efficiently managed the HVAC system, resulting in a more efficient energy use, and it demonstrated to be an important tool in the sustainable design of human-centric environments. However, since occupants frequently lack knowledge of the optimal settings and may not be familiar with the building's operations, it is crucial to explore the implementation of automatic and real-time adjustments in building facility systems. This is where Occupant-Centric Control and this study come into play, bridging the gap by understanding human needs and translating them into real-world environmental conditions, thereby bringing people closer to their built environment. The economic aspect and comfort profiles are intricately interconnected [79]. Often, meeting occupant comfort preferences involves higher energy consumption and, consequently, increased economic expenditure compared to standard operating conditions. As a result, this work is focused on the development of an OCC strategy that not only ensures occupant comfort but also takes into account the economic dimension. It is demonstrated that achieving economic savings is feasible by striking a balance between two comfort domains. Additionally, the efficacy of employing specialized HVAC control methodologies to manipulate the thermodynamic properties of the supply air flow, enable us to attain energy and economic savings. Nevertheless, it is important to address certain limitations of this study. Although the subjects had different body compositions and activity levels, they shared a similar lifestyle, performed the same job, and fell within a similar age range. In future tests, it is imperative to expand the sample size to include a more representative population. This will help determine whether the model performs better when specific boundaries and parameters are outlined. Additionally, future studies should explore the cross-effects of different domains, examining how the mutual adjustment of parameters can lead to an even more optimized building system solution. Other domains, such as the visual aspect, should also be investigated, finding a balance between lighting settings, comfort perception, and physiological responses. Moving forward, it is essential to implement the automated regulation of building systems in a real environment using the model outputs. This will allow for a comparison between the actual consequences on energy consumption and occupant comfort and the results obtained from the simulation. Furthermore, by exploiting the simulation tool, the proposed model could be enhanced by incorporating additional features to account for scenarios where multiple individuals occupy a room, such as shared offices. Despite the potential advancements that can be made, this study serves as a foundational starting point for the exploration of Occupant-Centric Control, addressing issues that have not yet been tackled by the scientific community. 8 Conclusions This paper proposes an Occupant-Centric Control technique for the design and operation of smart HVAC systems that takes into consideration the physiological response of the human body to optimize building energy performance and occupant comfort. The study aims to evaluate the potentials of the proposed PCM implemented in a BEPS tool with the goal of addressing the linkage between the indoor environment, the human body, and the HVAC system, as well as bridging the gap between human demands and the built environment by translating occupant comfort criteria into actual environmental conditions. A highly flexible Personal Comfort Model was, thus, developed for the accurately predicting thermal sensations and CO2 intakes of occupants; the model’s accuracy was verified by means of an extensive multi-domain experimental campaign. The PCM based on the physiological response of the human body was modelled and implemented in a flexible dynamic simulation tool where a Model Predictive Control was developed for the design of a control strategy for HVAC systems that effectively addresses the occupants’ thermal comfort and air quality requirements in indoor spaces. The developed strategy relies on a multilevel non-linear programming optimization procedure to determine optimal hygrothermal setpoints. The model's reliable predictive capabilities were effectively verified through a validation procedure conducted by using experimental data; results show that the skin temperature offset falls within the ±2 % error band 97 % and 84 % of the time for the all the experimental tests. In addition, the PCM exhibited flexibility in accommodating different subjects and levels of metabolic activity. The proposed OCC strategy employed an MLNLP optimization procedure to determine optimal hygrothermal setpoints, resulting in thermal energy savings of 3.7 % and 20 % for cooling and heating tests, respectively. Moreover, the strategy provided maximum comfort, with no hours of discomfort during the occupation time. The MPC strategy efficiently managed the HVAC system, resulting in operating cost savings of 12.8 % and 7.8 % for test 1 and test 2, respectively. The study emphasizes the significance of centralized HVAC system control to address the real and personalized comfort needs of occupants, while minimizing operating costs to achieve sustainability and building efficiency objectives. Overall, this research opens promising paths for creating energy-efficient and occupant-focused building environments. The study represents a significant advancement in the sustainable design of human-centric spaces toward energy efficiency and occupant comfort. Future work aims to implement this strategy in real-life tests to evaluate its effectiveness in occupied environments. Additionally, conducting this analysis in different climates will provide valuable guidelines for occupant-centric control, enabling the assessment of maximum achievable savings. coredata.dc:description: Occupant Centric Control (OCC) strategies aims to achieve a more personalized and comfortable indoor environment, translating occupants' comfort requirements into real environmental conditions. This strategy relies on a multilevel non-linear programming optimization procedure to determine optimal thermo-hygrometric setpoints. The objective is to minimize space heating and cooling requirements while addressing multi-domain comfort concerns related to individual thermal sensations and perceived air quality. To facilitate this process, this study adopts a novel Personal Comfort Model (PCM), incorporating physiological factors to predict occupants' thermal sensations and CO2 intakes. The PCM's reliable predictive capabilities are confirmed through validation with real experimental data from a test room at the University of Perugia. For detailed energy analyses, considering occupants' subjective comfort preferences, the PCM is seamlessly integrated into DETECt, an in-house building energy performance simulation tool developed by the University of Naples Federico II, for the design of advanced control algorithms and energy efficiency strategies. To effectively manage the HVAC system, a model predictive control is implemented, using the determined setpoints to ensure mechanical ventilation and maximize cost savings. The proof of concept for the developed methodology involves simulating experimental tests using the thermal model of the human body and the new facility management system, to be simulated and optimized by means of the enhanced building energy performance simulation tool, exploited for the design and operation of more occupant-centric and sustainable buildings. The proposed study demonstrates that through the developed OCC strategy enables a significant reduction in thermal discomfort (40 % and 60 % less than the occupation time for test 1 and test 2, respectively) compared to reference scenarios. Additionally, energy analysis reveals high efficiency, achieving savings of 12.8 % and 7.8 % of electricity consumed for HVAC system operation.
